bibl.title: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Wade Hampton Frost, September 26, 1930

div1.p: Carter sends Frost bills she has received for the maps and thanks him for the Editor's Note for Section I of the book.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Wade Hampton Frost, September 26, 1930
div1.opener:
Book, Misel
Maps.
Bills
(Maps etc)
The Westmoreland,
2122 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.,
September 26, 1930.
Dr. Wade H. Frost,
School of Hygiene and Public Health,
615 North Wolfe Street,
Baltimore, Maryland.
Dear Jack:
div1.p:
1: Mr. F. Irvine Burnham has just brought me the enclosed bill for
$125.00 for compiling and drafting the three maps to accompany Father's
book.

Mr. Burhham says that he has made a 50% reduction in his bill(, which
he computed in accordance with the time spent in compiling and drafting
the maps) on account of having had to turn them over to you before he
had finished working up various details, which would help in the reproduc-
tion of the maps. These details, he feels can be attended to when the
platts for the maps are made, but regrets not having had time to do them
himself.

2: I am also enclosing receipted bill for negatives (photostats of
Bor et al.) It may be that you already have a duplicate of this. I paid for
them, or rather sent Miss Brown the money to pay for them. I am therefore
merely sending it as a Memorandum, in case you need it in turning in your
accounts. It came to $3.10.

3: Thank you very much for the Editor's note for Section i, which
has just reached me, together with your letter of transmittal and the ori-
ginal page 5 of Father's MS. You have handled the matter perfectly.

Still losing weight, and “feeling accordingly.” However, I am
taking all the care of myself that is feasible and I hope, with cooler
weather, to get back to a point where living isn't a physical burden. The
thought of the completion of the book makes life worth-while, even though
it be uncomfortable!

Its late, and I must hurry to catch the last collection of mail.
It was good to see you and Susan the other day! My love to her and to
Little Susan and to yourself my profound gratitude and satisfaction at the
very perfect work on the Early History of Yellow Fever.
